dt: {bc}a nervous or fearful feeling of uncertain agitation {bc}{sx|apprehension||}

pt: {sc}fear{/sc} {sc}dread{/sc} {sc}fright{/sc} {sc}alarm{/sc} {sc}panic{/sc} {sc}terror{/sc} {sc}trepidation{/sc} mean painful agitation in the presence or anticipation of danger. {sc}fear{/sc} is the most general term and implies anxiety and usually loss of courage.
{sc}dread{/sc} usually adds the idea of intense reluctance to face or meet a person or situation and suggests aversion as well as anxiety.
{sc}fright{/sc} implies the shock of sudden, startling fear.
{sc}alarm{/sc} suggests a sudden and intense awareness of immediate danger.
{sc}panic{/sc} implies unreasoning and overmastering fear causing hysterical activity.
{sc}terror{/sc} implies the most extreme degree of fear.
{sc}trepidation{/sc} adds to {sc}dread{/sc} the implications of timidity, trembling, and hesitation.

quotes.t: I came aboard the 319 with {qword}trepidation{/qword}, to join the lives of utter strangers, a man untried by the circumstances they had known.

subsource.source: in {it}Authors at Sea{/it}, Robert Shenk, ed.

quotes.t: In the first minutes, hours, or even days of fieldwork most researchers feel {qword}trepidation{/qword} about being an outsider, a stranger on the scene …
This was an ambitious project, and a number of us felt some {qword}trepidation{/qword} about the possible results.

et: Latin {it}trepidation-, trepidatio{/it}, from {it}trepidare{/it} to tremble, from {it}trepidus{/it} agitated; probably akin to Old English {it}thrafian{/it} to urge, push, Greek {it}trapein{/it} to press grapes
shortdef: a nervous or fearful feeling of uncertain agitation : apprehension
